I had always thought there was quite a bit of real estate that could be taken advantage of with the extruder fan assembly. Thanks to bluejay117's work and sharing of the source for this puppy (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:64669). Sorry for bastardizing any favored fillets, I'm a baboon on crack in CAD ;) I threw an incredibly cramped fitting for a little 5mm led headlight. Included are stls both Serif and Sans Serif and a STEP file. In Action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CXka9GoqYeU

Layer Height (mm): .15
Number of shells: 3
Time Travel Feedrate(mp/h): 88 What you do after that.... I hope I get to see. I'm off to figure out how to get an ADXL335 to put on a light show with 2x9 NeoPixel strips along the Y Axis build platform arms. Accelerometer RAVE Have fun.

description.text:
This R/C car shock stand can be used for 1:10 shocks to empty and fill in the oil. To empty the shock put it upside down to the stand. The bottom of the container is so formed ( V-Shape ) that the oil can be easily removed. To store the stand, the plate with the holes can be placed into the container and the cover closed it (use a rubber band to fix it).
Note: Maybe your shocks are larger than mine, so feel free to stretch the container in its height! Use the Top and Base STL files for printing. The cover has a small flap on one of its edges. This is only to remove it easily from you printer bed. Can be removed with a sharp knife. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iqbh60C5gAa

title: IKEA Gommaren Shower Curtain Rod Support

description.text:
The IKEA Gommaren shower curtain rod is designed to be cantilevered but in reality it sags after time especially when heavier (read: better quality) shower curtains are used.   
This design demonstrates that one corner can be propped up, lending support to the overall frame. I have a 1/2" wire trunking screwed to the wall as a support for Bygel containers as planters - not everything needs to be printed :-)  so that trunk lends support.  
My bathroom set up is probably unique but hopefully this gives you an idea if you are faced with a sagging Gommaren :)

description.text:
Modelo topográfico de Sierra Nevada, provincia de Granada al sur de España. Se distinguen los picos mas altos de la cordillera Mulhacen (3480 m), Veleta (3393) y Alcazaba (3371 m)
Creado a partir de datos LIDAR descargados desde el centro de descargas del IGN (Instituto Geográfico Nacional)
http://www.ign.es/ign/main/index.do
Los datos están disponibles en malla de 5 metros en proyección UTM. Para la obtención del modelo STL, se ha usado DEMto3d, una herramienta útil y fácil de usar para covertir MDE (modelos digitales de elevaciones) en modelos STL, listos para imprimir en 3D. DEMto3D está disponible en la siguiente dirección: http://www.demto3d.com/
DEMto3D funciona como una extensión disponibles para los softwares SIG gratuitos Kosmo (http://www.opengis.es/) y QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)

Topography model of Sierra Nevada located in Granada, south of Spain. The highest peaks of the Cordillera are observed: Mulhacen (3480 m), Veleta (3393) and Castle (3371 m). Created from LIDAR data downloaded from spanish agency IGN http://www.ign.es/ign/main/index.do?locale=en
The data are posted on a 5 m grid UTM proyected. To obtain the STL model, I used DEMto3d, an easy and useful tool to convert DEM data to STL models ready to print. This tool is available in the next link http://www.demto3d.com/
DEMto3D is a plugin available for free GIS software Kosmo (http://www.opengis.es/) and QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)

I've searched thingiverse for a dummy security camera to place in front of my apartment, didn't be able to find a good one. So designed my own.  
The camera lens inside is actually a wide angle LED lens which is available on the market. Even without it the cam will look very real.  
There are 4 holes for 3mm leds that will imitate IR lighting leds inside the cameras. There is empty space inside so if you like you can place a circuit to flash them, or anyhting else. Even a real camera can be fitted in, making my design not a dummy but a real security cam. Ebay is full of small cameras, many of them wireless that can fit inside.   
There is also a dummy wireless antenna thing on top.  
Added an extra part designed by Cooasty for making the cam a little bit more manouvreable. Thanks Cooasty.
Added an extension part after a request from Va_Le for the ones who want to put a 9V or other type of battery inside. Thanks Va_Le

description.text:
I created the Vampire Lord for the Skyrim DLC: Dawnguard. I decided to take the zbrush model I made for it and turn it into this bust for my own personal use. I was however given permision to share it with you guys for anyone that may be a Skyrim fan or just wants a cool looking creature in general. Vampire Lord is property of Bethesda Games Studios. Feel free to print and enjoy this model but please do not alter it or try to sell it in any way, it is illegal and they will find out, trust me. Other than that Print Away! If you enjoy this model feel free to drop by my page and say hi, as well as see some other stuff I am working on. Any questions/feedback welcome :) http://www.facebook.com/DennisMejillones Video of it being printed
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wZCjIyomjAQ

This Thing was printed in PLA. It is composed of two models, the main bust and some small horns that are printed seperately. I have supplied some images with some colors that show you what to remove and where to add the horns. The red tinted is support structures to remove and the green are where the horns go. It was sliced with KisSlicer here are the settings: Skin Thickness: 0.6
loops:2
Extrusion Width: 0.4
Infill Extrusion Width: 0.4
Layer Thickness: 0.04
Temp: 1st layer-216, 2nd Layer-180 Fan on at all times and if possible a large fan cooling the whole part
50% infill
Speed: Perimiter-20, Solid Infill-50, Sparse-70

author: MicroMake

description.text:
Despite what you see in the spy movies, what people call a "silencer" can't really be done in any size smaller than a beer bottle. Printed on normal 3D printers, this is a sound moderator: It won't eliminate the sound of an airgun firing, but will cut out the sharp "crack" that makes birds fly off and wives complain from the study.
It works by allowing the excess gas from the barrel to expand slowly in a series of chambers, shown in the cutaway image. If you use this with a firearm you will probably melt it.

Adjust barrel diameter and calibre settings in SCAD file, print, fasten to airgun barrel with stainless steel hose clamp. Supplied STL is for a 12mm diameter barrel in 5.56mm (.22) calibre.
Apply standard firearm safety practices when aligning the moderator with the centre of the barrel. i.e. don't look down the bloody thing when it is loaded!
If your 3D printer has a lot of headroom, enable the 4th segment in the SCAD file.

comments.author: NETio

comments.text: actually making any device that alters the report of a firearm can be considered a suppressor by BATF that includes a bottle, baby bottle nipple, potato ect. I do believe the way its written is you cant make any device that can be installed on a firearm that would diminish the report of a firearm even by 1db without proper forms files and tax stamp secured. Any device made to diminish the report perform as a suppressor for airguns and paintball markers has to be submitted for approval by the BATF as not firearms capable. as for the thought so long as you don't have that caliber of weapon you can make a suppressor for one that's just not true at all. Ok so who am I? no one just a guy who has applied many times for tax stamps to build real firearms suppressors and someone who has read and understands the laws governing said devices. I'm not bashing anyone here you do what ever floats your boat, but make sure you have read and understand the laws airguns manufacturers are being permitted to add such devices because they are permanent to the airgun and cant be removed and installed onto a powder burner. That all said I did read on some forums that if your permanently affixing the device to the airgun its ok, but I don't recall ever reading that in the laws so until I do I'm not ever willing to take the chance. permanent being welded, pined and welded over.
comments.author: NETio

This is a Qi Charger Housing I designed to fit 2 well known Qi charger designs. It allows you to wirelessly charge and view your phone in a horizontal or vertical position and the phone should be stable. The first is a cheap QI charger which is all over ebay. I've posted a picture of it in the gallery (dimensions of 69mm x 10mm) The second Qi charger it fits is an Expower Super Mini Qi Charger (dimensions of 60mm x 11.8mm). Amazon link here:
http://goo.gl/Vk2L6h The zip file contains both sizes, print whichever one you need. If i get enough requests for other sizes, I will add them also. There is the option to buy or make some little feet to stick on the base of the legs to keep it in one place (but it's not necessary). Also you will need to buy one of those real cheap car phone holder pads on Ebay. You can get a couple for 99p sometimes. All you need to do is to cut out the four triangle'ish shapes and glue them in the holes on the four phone supports. You can then place your phone horizontally or vertically and in an easy to view angle and the phone should stay put. Enjoy, hope you all like it! My first proper contribution to Thingiverse Cheers Mark

I was tired of waiting hours for a bracelet to print only to have it come out looking less than stellar. I set out to create a "system" that allows you to print and form bracelet designs without having to wait for hours or making guesses on sizing. To use my system all you need is a design for your print flat bracelet, one wrist measurement, and a little hot water. My system consists of the following parts:
-Sizing chart
-Sizing mandrels
-Print flat bracelets I have included six sizes of mandrels that should work for most people. Also included are two Large sized bracelets for test printing. Shortly I will be releasing the two bracelet designs in all six "standard" sizes for simple printing. Heart Key Print Flat Bracelet in all six sizes
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:680850 You do not need to use the mandrels to get good results as you can use my sizing chart, print an appropriately sized bracelet and use your wrist to form the bracelet. The mandrels make creating bracelets for other people really easy and reduce the possibility of hurting someone with scalding hot water.

First you need to obtain a wrist measurement. Once you have this, find the mandrel with the closest circumference to your measurement (slightly smaller works better than slightly larger. For example if you have 180 mm wrist use the 175 mm mandrel). If you are not using the mandrels you can find this information in PrintFlatBraceletSystemInstructions.pdf Print a bracelet with a length equal to the reccommended length found in PrintFlatBraceletSystemInstructions.pdf . Heat the bracelet in hot water (nearly boiling) take the noodle consistency bracelet out of the water and wrap around the mandrel or around your wrist. For more detailed instructions please see the PrintFlatBraceletSystemInstructions.pdf Please note you must print the bracelets in PLA for this to work. Bracelets take between 10-30 minutes to print
Forms take between 2-3 hours to print
(Time based on Printrbot Simple Metal)

5) Place on top of bowl with the bolts in the holes of the bowl
6) screw nuts on under side of bowl

Tried a lot of different approaches but the noise wouldn't really go away. This model is designed to be used with 4 HDD silencers (had them lying around for nearly a decade :) and 8 standard 3mm screws (pretty short though).  
I just measured the noise with "dB Meter" for iPhone at a distance of ~30-40cm. Before: 69 - 71 dB, after: 59 - 61 dB. I don't really know if the app is calibrated correctly because i just downloaded it to give you these values but i can tell you that i'm pretty happy with this design. The noise-volume drops a lot.  
Time will tell how durable the construction is. The top silencers could soften a bit... but we'll see if that ever happens.
Printed it with 100% fill hoping for best durability.

It's a gusset that can be added in to your design to reinforce walls that are prone to warping in a specific direction due to the design of your part.
I was dissapointed to wake up to a 14 hr print where a wall had warped in a strange way (the red part).  It actually looks like a y-axis shift, but it isn't.  The other 2 walls are fine.  Upon closer inspection, I observed that the wall was collapsing towards the back of the machine and 'recovered' once it reached a larger mass section giving the appearance of a shift.  I fixed this one with a dremel and some ABS glue.  
When it came time to print its mirror sister in pink, I tried adding in some gussets to support the wall that had collapsed.  I used 4 of them evenly spaced.  It worked quite well.  Sorry about the blurry pic.  I didn't check it before I cut the gussets off.
This works well when  you know exactly where your part is prone to warping.

Using your favorite mesh editing program, align the bottom of the part and the bottom of the gusset to the same plane.  Scale if necessary.  Move/Rotate Gusset so that it is supporting the wall that needs to be reinforced.  The chamfered tip can be aligned so that it just barely enters the wall it is supporting.  
After printing, cut off with some wire snips and sand if needed.  If you placed it right, you will not need to patch.

author: handystore

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

Taking a quilting pantograph, I turned it into a single line design for the eggbot. Happy Valentine's Day!
WARNING: This was created in Inkscape 0.91, which defines 1" as 90 DPI. Inkscape 0.92 defines 1" as 96 DPI. When I retool my file at home, it will be uploaded as V2.

I was having problems with my eggbot and calibration issues (mainly because the table it was on was kind of shaky, and the slightest nudge would push things out of calibration), so I was looking up designs that had minimal pen-lifting. As one of my other hobbies is quilting, and I've been drooling over robot-quilting rigs for years, I thought, hey! I could use a quilting pantograph for eggbot designs! And so, here we are.
I took a JPG into Inkscape, and plotted it out, area by area.

Here is a plain pencil holder and one inscribed with 12 copies of the word "Pencil" in a nice clean font.  A recent development version of openSCAD was used.  The development version nicely integrates various fonts into openSCAD and makes it easy to use text.  OpenSCAD code for the pencil holders is included.
To run the openSCAD code download the latest development version from the openSCAD web site.

description.text:
With air path to hot end and nozzle. Fan is modelled although will need purchasing separately.  
PCB not yet produced to connect to FAB.  
Model may need modding and is not tested.  
Has now been test fitted for size but not operational.  
EDIT: Fixed PCB cover to top section of mount, added fixing holes and locking mechanisms, added hole at rear for wires to extruder.  
EDIT: Altered air path to nozzle to allow for different 5v blower, added mount for nozzle blower, included pins to allow for fixing of Air Path to Lower section (advise using epoxy), Altered method of fixing upper & lower parts to allow for snap together fixing - screw holes still included if needed.  
EDIT: I have tested this for fit and it fouls the rear case (if you have it fitted), also the hot end doesn't stick out enough so this will not work in its current form. I am trying to re-design it.

description.text:
I wanted to be able to make my own base using StefanHH's ball socket part, because the ball in BallSocket fits well in the socket, but the ball in his BallFlange part doesn't. title: Transparent CTC 3D Printer Filament Tube Holder

description.text:
I made these for my Transparent Acrylic Case CTC printer that I got from Ebay in February 2014.. it's been a great printer, but it had no place for Filament Tubes to mount.. These pieces keep the filament tube farther back and higher than usual which allows the use of bigger spools of filament such as the triple thick spools for PushPlastic.. You'll need to print out 2 of these pieces.. one for each side.. They clip on tight but I also use a tiny bit of clear packing tape to make sure they don't go anywhere.. You can see that in the photo.. If your filament tube is a little too small for the opening just put a little scotch tape around your tube till it fits tight. I have tubes here that fit tight and some that require some tape to fit tight.. Note..This will not fit a CTC Case with a wooden frame..
For a wooden frame CTC try this..
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:678542

author: zic3799

title: Super Light Quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The aim of this project is to maximize the flight time/ battery life of the very famously fun Hubsan X4 quadcopter. I only used spare parts from the Hubsan H107L model. The weight of this chassis is only 4.18g plus battery clip 0.49g. The whole quadcopter including chassis, clip, LED's, motors, propellers and receiver is only 21g. Excluding battery, that is 25% lighter than the original H107L model which weight 27.8g. Even loaded with a 380mAh battery it´s just 3.5g heavier than H107L without its battery. With battery: 31.35g compared to commercial 38.15g. Continuous flight time with a 380mAh battery was measured to 11.5 minutes. I don´t have a H107L to compare with but it should be a difference. Please let me know it you have one. Due to its low weight it´s also very quick and reactive. A great fun to play with. It´s robust enough to fly with but don't except it to take too serious damage. It´s optimized for weight, not robustness. Maybe if you print it with 100% infill and another material it could take more damage. I include the original Rhino CAD file if anyone wants to modify the construction for improvements. It could easily be converted for the stronger 8mm motors for example. For more details of what parts to buy and how to actually build it, please follow this link:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Super-Light-Quadcopter/ The print consists of a body that fit original hubsan parts from h107L, including receiver, 7x20mm motors, 3mm LED´s and battery. The clip will hold the battery and I upgraded it to also fixate the cable. Update 2015-02-16: Adjusted battery cable clip for better fit. http://youtu.be/ML9STN5LbJ8

The body is best printed upside down. For more robustness, print it with 100% infill. I used Simplify3D with very good result together with Wanhao Duplicator 4x printer and PLA material. For more detailed settings, please see images from Simplify3D. I recommend using manual support structure according to images. I also include my project files for Simplify3D if you want to use exactly my settings and support structure. Extrusion width: 0.46mm
Layer height: 0.1mm
Top solid layers: 5
Bottom solid layers: 5
Shells: 1
Infill: 10% with 50% extrusion width @ 75 & -25 degrees
Support infill: 30% and offset 0,25mm
Temp extruder: 218C
Temp bed: 60C The battery clip using same settings except printer width=0.42mm and extrusion multiplier=0.99.

comments.text: replacement of breakage of the shell, to do this without soldering.

title: Cross product direction finder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Helps you find the direction of the cross product (or vector product) of two arbitrary vectors, without distorting your hand with a "right hand rule".  Useful in math and physics classes (especially when working with torque or magnetism).  Prints in two pieces, which snap together to form a hinge.  No support needed.  50% or greater infill recommended.  Parametrized (OpenSCAD) file included.

• Modify and recompile if desired. (I just use "1" and "2" to represent the two vectors, so you might want to change that, for example.)
  • Print the two pieces (together or separately). I recommend an infill of 50% or greater. I have tested this with PLA plastic and 0.150 mm between layers, but I don't think it matters that much.
  • Insert one post at the end of the arm into the corresponding hole in the base, so that the "1" and "2" are on top of each other (and both facing up). Carefully push the other post down until it snaps into its hole. (You may need to use a key or flat screwdriver blade to do this.)
  • If desired, color the writing ("1", "2", and "1x2") so that it stands out. I've had good luck just using White-Out or a Sharpie.

remixed_from.title: Spool Holder for UP or AFINIA

title: Remix of Spool Holder for UP or AFINIA by umeznet, published Apr 20, 2014

description.text:
Found a lot of spool holders, didn't find many that were well designed aside from this one. I made a few tweaks: I added a filament tube holder boss at the top so the tube is actually held in place. I also got rid of the little boss that wraps around the front of the printer, no need for it, just wastes support material and takes longer to print. One thing that needs to be done: the top hole should have been counterbored like the bottom one. Edit 2/14/15: RevC. got several spools all different sizes and decided to improve this again. I have 2lb spools and the original really wasn't strong enough.
-I beefed up the rib,
-made it to fit 3.75" width spools
-removed the little nub that retains the spool created a retainer clip that slides up against any width spool with spring tension.

title: Parametric Lego Mindstorms Mecanum Monster Wheel 120 mm

description.text:
Parametric Lego Mindstorms Mecanum Monster Wheel 120 mm. The Mecanum Wheel can be printed without any support structures. Needed Parts for building a single wheel:
  • 12x MecanumWheel4_Roller
  • 1x MecanumWheel4_Left (or MecanumWheel4_Right)
  • 12x Lego Axle 5L (length=39.6 mm, PartNr 32073)
    • The roller's profile has been generated based on following model:
    http://www.chiefdelphi.com/media/papers/download/2749 Remarks:
  • To build a four wheel robot one needs 2 left wheels and 2 right wheels. It is possible to drive sideways using these wheels
  • The current model is fully printed in PLA. It might be better to print the rollers in Ninjaflex or perhaps paint the PLA rollers with rubber paint to avoid slipping of the wheels.
  • Printing the base of the wheel in PLA is much easier then printing it in ABS. So I recommend using PLA for the base of the wheel.
    • For an alternative version (82 mm wheels) of this design see:
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:641377 The Wheels in action:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qqZeQW2j3Wo&feature=youtu.be The Wheels in action with Ninjaflex rollers:
    https://youtu.be/jbsZJ-u7Ckk

title: Relay Fix for DC Extruder Motor Thing-O-Matic

description.text:
Different wiring of the relays removes risk of shorting the power supply, so no need for diodes to motor, but I added a resistance of 8 Ohms as additional security (in case the motor decides to short internally, probably not necessary).
Also, there are no capacitors, because they might influence reaction speed of relays.
I did the schematics with "fritzing", somehow they don't look as fancy and understandable as other schematics seen around here. What software do you use to draw schematics (on a mac) ?
This absolutely solved the erratic bahaviour of the DC Extruder Motor, who is now ready to print correctly the parts for a stepper extruder. :-)
Oh and yes, if you build this and the motor spins backward instead of forward, just invert the cables which go to the motor. :-)

This was designed as an industrial design project it may need some re scaling and work

The Tobii X2-60 (http://www.tobii.com/) is a great piece of equipment used for eye tracking in research environments. The only problem is that the EPU (External Processing Unit), which is basically a little computer, has to sit on a desk in front of the subject. If you have subjects with hands that like to push buttons and grab things then this is a problem. Working with children, we knew there had to be a better solution. A mounting bracket that attached to the back of a monitor using standard VESA mount hardware would be ideal. Tobii doesn't offer such a mounting bracket, so we made one. I'm pretty pleased with the simple design. It's not fancy, but it works. If you aren't constantly moving your monitor around, I don't think you'll run into trouble with the EPU falling out. That said, It's probably a good idea to remove the EPU from the bracket if you are moving the monitor. Also included is an offset version of the bracket (X260HolderArmMountHolder/Bracket). These two fit together and must be glued or otherwise joined permanently. The offset might be a bit much, so I've included the source file in case someone wants to change that. There's also a small spacing bracket to act as a shim in order to keep the arm mount parallel to the monitor. Developed by Graham Holt (https://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=32946354)
Laboratory of Cognitive Neuroscience (http://www.childrenshospital.org/research-and-innovation/research/labs/laboratories-of-cognitive-neuroscience)
Boston Children's Hospital (http://www.childrenshospital.org/). This object was modeled in FreeCAD (http://www.freecadweb.org/).

Just something I quickly hacked together to be able to feed my printer from a second Robox spool which is not in the printer. I had some ~10mm plastic pipe laying around, so I used that to connect sides of the holder together and also as an axle that goes through the spool. Version 2 of the middle path has teeth to grap the reel. This way the same setup can be used to spool different filaments on a Robox SmartReel using a drill. Version 3 has a slot to accommodate for manually winching filament on the spool. Version 4 has a square hole through the whole adapter. A crank arm and related parts are only needed for this.
A round axle and robox adapter is recommended is crank arm will not be used. I also added a taller version to accommodate for bigger 1kg spools. New spool adapters fit 3DPrima, Colorfabb and Taulman spools. These are not mandatory as the center of these spools is already a round hole (unlike Robox SmartReels which pretty much require an adapter for smooth use). Note that these reels are also wider than the robox reels, so make the holder and axle wide enough if you plan to use different reels.

I printed from PLA using ~15-20% infill. 4 top and bottom layers, 3 perimiters. No scaling for any parts except for the crank axle, where I used the scaled down version.  
If printing from ABS (or other materials) scale up to keep the original size, so reels will still fit as expected.

remixed_from.author: droftarts
remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text: I, like many Mini owners, was surprised at the noise such a wee machine could make. I measured normal printing noise at about 96-102 db. Yes, it was a noisy beast. But not so much anymore! Now the same print is down to 72-80 db. How did I do this? I printed new idler pulleys for the front pulleys that have 20 GT2 teeth. These toothed pulleys :) reduce noise caused by the flat surface stock rollers. You will need 2 of these and, yes, you can print them on your Mini. Just wear ear protection. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627 as the basis for creating this pulley. Use at your own risk, your mileage (noise) may vary, etc., etc. Enjoy!

WARNING: This mod could possibly void your warranty. Use at your own risk!  
Print 2 idler pulleys. Use standard or high setting.  
Allow Mini's extruder to cool then turn off and unplug the power cord.  
The idler pulleys are located in the top front corners of the machine. You sort of have to stick your head partly into the machine to find them. Just follow the belt.  See photos.  
Do one side at a time.  
Use a 2.5mm allen wrench and remove the bolt securing the pulley. Make sure to keep track of the nut on top of the pulley mount. Pull the bolt out and then remove the pulley.  
The pulley has 2 bearings that are pressed in. Carefully use the long end of the allen wrench to push out each bearing applying pressure on one side then another until you work them out. Don't use excessive force. In fact, hide all of your hammers, drills, and other sharp objects first. The bearings are pretty sturdy but if you damage one, you may have to search long and pay dearly for a replacement.  
Did I mention this may void your warranty?  
Once the bearings are removed, press them into the new idler. They should fit really tight. If too tight, you can use a heat gun to heat the pulley (not the bearing) until the bearings press in. Use caution when doing this as a heat gun can burn you if your accidentally touch the nozzle while hot.   
Install the new idler taking care to ensure the belt is properly positioned on all of its rollers and the stepper motor in the rear. You will need to use moderate pressure to hold the idler in place while you insert the bolt.  
Repeat for the opposite side and enjoy your somewhat quieter (but by no means silent) Makerbot Mini! :)

comments.author: oliasmage

comments.text: Ok, sounds like a classic layer shift. The source of most layer shifts are mechanical failures such as loose belts, pulleys, or broken axis components. If the shift is occurring in only one direction, you can narrow things down to the axis. For example, if the shifts are front-to-back, it is the Y axis and occurs when the carriage is moved forward and backward. If the shifts are left-to-right, it is the X axis.
comments.author: wtu007

comments.text: One other thought. If the build plate is not fully inserted or the locking mechanism is damaged, the build plate can move causing all manner of poor quality and print failures. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:615358 for a way to fix loose build plates.
